Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The independent analysis found some of the city's rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants. The report recommends changes that could lower the rent hikes tenants face each year, setting up what is sure to be a fierce debate at city hall.
Document Sources.Source Justification: the nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: What [the report] is trying to do is make a PR effort to lay the groundwork to chip away at what little ability landlords have in L.A. to be able to raise rents and be able to keep up with their costs
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Small landlords are able to maintain their profits and draw income above their expenses — they haven't been overly burdened by rent stabilization
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: I think when it's a politically contentious issue, there are attempts to manage the conversation. The substance of the report is final. It was submitted as a final report and accepted by the city as a final work product.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: There are several rounds of revisions left to go before this report is considered final. Economic Roundtable is under contract to complete this report through January 2025 — though clearly we hope to have it finalized before then.
